head.title: A Look Into the Mirror of Race

hedline.hl1: A Look Into the Mirror of Race

abstract.p: Molly Guptill letter says race is perhaps most visible and invisible chasm dividing our society and inhibiting progress (July 2 front page article)

block.p: Re ''The Minority Quarterback: Coaches Chose a White to Call the Plays. The Campus Found That Hard to Swallow'' (''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, July 2):

Your article looked at race in a way that is not common in our society -- with a white person representing the minority. Although Marcus Jacoby, the quarterback, transferred to another college, leaving the tensions and fears of a minority student behind, those who are minorities in American society do not have this luxury. People of color cannot escape from the daily pain, threats and violence.
Re ''The Minority Quarterback: Coaches Chose a White to Call the Plays. The Campus Found That Hard to Swallow'' (''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, July 2):

Your article looked at race in a way that is not common in our society -- with a white person representing the minority. Although Marcus Jacoby, the quarterback, transferred to another college, leaving the tensions and fears of a minority student behind, those who are minorities in American society do not have this luxury. People of color cannot escape from the daily pain, threats and violence.

In many respects, America is a great nation. But race is perhaps the most visible and invisible chasm dividing our society and inhibiting the progress of our businesses, schools and the nation as a whole. The cycle of hate, mistrust and fear fostered during centuries of inequality must be brought to a halt.
